Persons who have known him well over many years say there is no more honest man in
Italian public life than Mario Soelba. But even some of his friends and strong supporters

Somehow, the government seamed to get itself on the defensive. There is no evidence

It is evident that much damage has been done to the standing of the Soelba government
and. therefore, to the Italian democracy by this affair. A Home correspondent of the great
Turin newspaper, I* Stamps, remarked recently that neither the Trieste accord "nor the other

But, ae I indicated earlier, the Montesi case is not the only factor in the present
